title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch first Starlink deployment mission since problem strikes satellite
summary: The Starlink 6-88 will add 29 broadband internet satellites to the constellation of more than 9,300 in low Earth orbit. Liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is scheduled for 12 a.m. EST (0500 UTC).

title: SpaceX, China drive new record for orbital launches in 2025
summary:

title: New Spanish communications satellite suffers ‘space particle’ impact
summary:
A Spanish military communications satellite launched in October was struck by what its operator described as a “space particle,” an incident that could jeopardize the spacecraft’s mission.

title: Spain’s New Communications Satellite Suffers “Space Particle” Strike
summary:
Indra Group has announced that the SpainSat NG II communications satellite was struck by a “space particle” as it was en route to its operational orbit. According to the company, it is currently assessing the extent of the damage. In 2019, Hisdesat selected a consortium led by Airbus, alongside Thales Alenia Space, to build two […]

title: SpaceX launches next second-generation Italian COSMO-SkyMed satellite
summary:
MILAN – A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifting off from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California, successfully launched a second-generation satellite for Italy’s COSMO-SkyMed Earth observation constellation, on Jan. 2 at 6:09 p.m. Pacific time.   The Falcon 9 deployed COSMO-SkyMed CSG-FM3, the third into a sun-synchronous orbit at an altitude of 618 kilometers at 2:22 […]

summary:

title: Curiosity's Nevado Sajama postcard captures Mars on the eve of conjunction
summary:
Los Angeles CA (SPX) Jan 03, 2026


From its perch on a rugged ridge in Gale Crater, NASA's Curiosity rover has stitched together a holiday postcard that doubles as a science panorama, framing the Nevado Sajama drill site against a hazy Martian sky. The scene merges two Mastcam mosaics taken on Nov. 18, 2025 - late afternoon on sol 4722 and early morning on sol 4723 - then tinted in cool blues and warm golds to emphasize changing

title: Danish Mani mission to chart lunar terrain in 3D
summary:
Berlin, Germany (SPX) Jan 03, 2026


The University of Copenhagen will lead Denmark's first lunar mission, a European Space Agency project that will map the Moon's surface in three dimensions to support future landings and base construction. 

The Mani satellite will orbit the Moon's north and south polar regions, acquiring high-resolution images that can be combined into detailed elevation models.
